Topic.Title: Microsoft announces today that Win8 has 40 million licensees

Message.Msg: Yes boys, Windows 8 works just fine. Last week a FedEx truck delivered a large crate of Windows 8 to the headquarters of Best's ever-growing global enterprises. And the Best Technology Department has been busy upgrading each and every PC enterprise-wide. It is best to have everybody on the same state-of-the-art operating system, don't you know. But, how does this fine new OS from Microsoft make nvda stock go up by even one penny? Hummm? It's a slow news day again, right ibbey?

Topic.Title: NVDA is buying

Message.Msg: Please, it's not a $10 stock and the buyback increases shareholder value, not decreases. So maybe you need to post elsewhere if you can't make sense.

Topic.Title: So Best? If Jen chopped guidance by (-15%), shouldn't the stock fall by (-15%) too?

Message.Msg: So Dr. Bester? Is Jen's stock buy-back program like a domestic turkey? Jumping off a roof. It temporarily looks okay, right? While the flightless domestic turkey is in the air. It has the appearance of the no-fly turkey, well, actually flying. But Gravity untimately wins, of course. When Jen quits using shareholder's cash to buy back stock. And the stock returns to earth. Plummetingly.

Topic.Title: So Best? If Jen chopped guidance by (-15%), shouldn't the stock fall by (-15%) too?

Message.Msg: So Master? Why aren't company stock buy-backs reported to the SEC on S-4 Forms? And disclosed like the next day? They really should be, you know. Just like any other insider trades in the company's stock. It's the same thing really. But rather than the "insider" trading his own stock -- he's trading on behalf of the company. With the shareholder's own cash. To make the stock price look better than it otherwise would be. Kinda like the Wizard of the Wizard of Oz. Behind the curtain pulling those levers and making impressive flames and this and that. Disclosing company stock buy-back transactions on Form S-4. Best, you should write to the SEC today about that superb idea. It would be like little dog Toto pulling back the curtain, right?

Topic.Title: A couple of pointers for retail shorties...

Message.Msg: well - lets see if volume picks up, else this is not real. I am willing to stay short here despite a small bounce. I will not flip to long side unless I see 12.80 level taken out on high volume. I expect a fade back to 11.5 as the fiscal cliff fear sets in. There are very few reasons to be long NVDA at this level. Even NVDA has not been pursuing stock buyback - read the fine print. NVDA Tegra business is still questionable. NVDA PC business is facing increasing competition from INTC. High end graphics is dependent on global economy. You do the math.

Message.Title: Why did NVDA announce a dividend when a "special one time cash dividend would have been better for shareholders?
Message.Msg: The probability that the current 15% tax rate on dividends will revert to the ordinary income rate come Jan. 1 has sparked a series of special payouts -- and that has Wall Street's attention. Did shareholders no favors with NVDA dividend announcement. Costco is giving a $7 special dividend to shareholders and stock ROSE, ROSE 4%.....go figure bagholders.

Message.Title: How frustrating is this?
Message.Msg: On a day like this NVDA should have broken 13 but here we are NVDA is barely green. Very fishy - something is amiss. Smells like a downgrade...

Topic.Title: How frustrating is this?

Message.Msg: "Very fishy - something is amiss. Smells" Sorry your short isn't doing as well as advertised...

Topic.Title: Why did NVDA announce a dividend when a "special one time cash dividend would have been better for shareholders?

Message.Msg: You really don't understand what Nvidia did. There is a dividend and buyback to show confidence in the future AND to increase shareholder value. If you can't see that, then maybe you need to take a class somewhere on basic arithmetic. The buyback clearly increases shareholder value and the dividend draws in the larger funds to make a long-term investment so the stock price stabilizes with anticipated growth. What you describe is a one time gift to appease investors fears in the short-term. I like what Costco is doing btw, but they also have a separate quarterly dividend too.

Just scalping at this point. Don't see any reason for conviction long.

Topic.Title: Sell AMD, NVDA and buy QCOM. QCOM 'new' chip is better... fact/ article.

Message.Msg: Besides the article being a blog and besides the fact that Qualcomm virtually has no presence in tablets and will not have certification for Windows 8 anytime soon and besides the fact the projected specs on the Tegra 4 are at least dubious, he is pointing out that Qualcomm is Nvidia's main competition. But your thesis about Nvidia going the route of AMD is silly.

Topic.Title: Sell AMD, NVDA and buy QCOM. QCOM 'new' chip is better... fact/ article.

Message.Msg: A fine, highly informative news article -- thanks for posting that. A few excerpts. "Qualcomm launched its range of Snapdragon S4 processors equipped with AMD’s mobile Radeon graphics earlier this year. Though its adoption is still in progress, benchmarks reveal that high-end Snapdragon S4 processors BEAT Nvidia’s Tegra 3 in terms of graphical performance BY A SIGNIFICANT MARGIN. Below are the benchmarks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GL Benchmark 2.5 Eqypt HD (Offseceen 1080p) Frames per Second - Higher is Better 29 __ Qualcomm S4 Pro/Adreno 320 2.5 GHz quad core processor 9 ___ nvidia tegra 3 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GL Benchmark 2.5 Eqypt Classic (Offseceen 1080p) Frames per Second - Higher is Better 78.2 __ Qualcomm S4 Pro/Adreno 320 2.5 GHz quad core processor 34.0 __ nvidia tegra 3 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- From the benchmarks, it seems that the market for high end gaming processors, at least performance-wise, Undeniably belongs to Qualcomm. Though smartphone manufacturer’s had a weaker quarter, Qualcomm reported stellar financial results. In my opinion, this run will continue as the demand for smartphones is increasing at a rapid rate, especially in India and China. The adoption of Qualcomm’s S4 is still in progress. The company is set to release Snapdragon S4 "Prime" processors in 2013. Though its GPU would be Adreno 320, the clock of the quad core processor would be stepped up from the current 1.7 GHz to 2.5 GHz. Nvidia is due to release its Tegra 4 processors in 2013, which would boast of a maximum clock of 2 Ghz, which is still lower than S4 Prime’s 2.5Ghz. In my opinion, Qualcomm is a great stock to hold, not because my smartphone also has a Snapdragon S4 chip, but because of its growth prospects." Wow! The nvidia Tegra #3 is clearly finished, competitively speaking. And it looks like the nvidia Tegra #4 is already D.O.A. -- Months before its release.

Topic.Title: Why did NVDA announce a dividend when a "special one time cash dividend would have been better for shareholders?

Message.Msg: Please "appease" us. After 19 long dividend-less years, we shareholders deserve more than a stinkin' $00.075 dividend per share. Four Bucks ($4.00) one-time, before year-end, please. Before the tax rates go up significantly next year, making the after-tax value of the dividend even more pathetic.

Topic.Title: AMD Plans to Sell 58 Acre Austin Site and Lease Back to raise Cash

Message.Msg: "Besides Intel has the Nvidia IP that they are paying for and Nvidia is providing our dividend from", writes j7777kxx, deceivingly. The pumper boy's highly naïve solution to Everything is the "Intel payment". But how many times can they spend the same Intel payment? Hummm? Look boys. The cold, cruel Reality is that Intel's LAST annual payment of $300 million is coming up really quick. January 15, 2013 to be exact. Then there's only three (3) little annual payments of just $200 million left. January 15, 2014 / January 15, 2015 / and January 15, 2016. And then Intel is Done paying nvidia for their IP -- Forever. Now, the other Inconvenient Fact is that the Tegra/Consuming Profits Business is on track to lose MORE than the entire Intel payment of $300 million. Yes, it will likely lose MORE, boys. For the Nine Months Ending October 28, 2012, the Tegra/Consuming Profits Division did in Fact lose ($233,545,000). That's nearly a Quarter of a Million Dollars -- in just 9 months. And annualizing that is what? ($311,393,000) Which is MORE than the aforementioned last $300 million payment from Intel. Is that not correct, decepticon j7777kxx? Speak up now, boy. Of course it is. So nvidia has Already spent the entire last Intel IP payment of $300 million. -- and then some -- on the Jen's horrendous loss-making Tegra folly. And keep in mind that thereafter the Intel payment falls to just $200 million per year. So in conclusion, the immutable Facts are: 1.) The Tegra/Consuming Profits Business is on track to lose MORE than the entire last Intel IP payment of $300 million, and, 2.) You can't spend the same Intel money more than once, boys. "Besides Intel has the Nvidia IP that they are paying for and Nvidia is providing our dividend from", writes j7777kxx, deceivingly.

Topic.Title: AMD Plans to Sell 58 Acre Austin Site and Lease Back to raise Cash

Message.Msg: So sorry for the typo. That should read, "Quarter of a Billion". For the Nine Months Ending October 28, 2012, the Tegra/Consuming Profits Division did in Fact lose ($233,545,000). That's nearly a Quarter of a BILLION Dollars -- in just 9 months. And annualizing that is what? ($311,393,000)
